column2:
COVID-19 negative certification required for entering the country.
People coming from red list countries must present a negative PCR test, taken 72h before entering the country as well as a valid vaccination certificate. Persons arriving from non-red list countries will be able to enter Moldova by showing a vaccination certificate, an antigen test or a PCR test.
column3:
Self-isolation at own accommodation- if not in possession of pre-requisite documents.
To enter Moldova, passengers who don’t hold any of the documents below, must complete an online epidemiological form that declares information about your state of health (relevant to the COVID pandemic) and confirm that you will self-isolate for 14 days unless you are exempt.
The following quarantine exemptions apply: • children up to the age of 12 are fully exempt
• people in transit, who are not spending more than 24 hours after their entrance was recorded in Moldova
• students coming for studies, exams, or academic contests upon presenting confirmation papers;
• crew and service personnel of aircraft, ships, and trains;
• persons summoned by Moldovan law enforcement institutions;
• persons traveling for health reasons, including the attendant;
• personnel involved in providing humanitarian aid;
• diplomatic passport holders and their family members accredited to the Republic of Moldova and International UN staff;
Arrivals who are in self-isolation may take a PCR test or a rapid antigen test on the 7th day of their visit, and will not have to continue self-isolating if the test is negative. You are allowed to enter the Transnistrian region without a negative PCR test.
column4: You will be exempt from self-isolation if you present proof that you have received both doses of an approved vaccination. The second dose must have been administered at least 14 days before your date of arrival. Current rules do not specify whether electronic documents are acceptable as proof, but you are recommended to present your vaccination certificate in paper form.
column5:
Latest News:

International Restrictions:
*Entry to Moldova: On 22 December 2021, the Ministry of Health established a new set of rules for entering Moldova, that will enter into force on 27 December 2021. People coming from red list countries must present a negative PCR test, taken 72h before entering the country as well as a valid vaccination certificate. Persons arriving from non-red list countries will be able to enter Moldova by showing a vaccination certificate, an antigen test or a PCR test.
The red list of countries can be found here: https://msmps.gov.md/ The Ministry of Health has established a new set of rules for entering Moldova. The red and green list of countries is no longer applicable.
To enter Moldova, passengers who don’t hold any of the documents below, must complete an online epidemiological form that declares information about your state of health (relevant to the COVID pandemic) and confirm that you will self-isolate for 14 days unless you are exempt.
The epidemiological form should be completed within 72h before your scheduled departure to Moldova and can be found via the following link: https://fisa-covid.gov.md/?lang=en You must complete the form online within 72 hours before your scheduled departure to Moldova. Specific exemptions are set out below, under Quarantine Requirements section.
All documents are accepted in the following languages: English, Romanian, Russian, French, Italian and German. More information on the entering rules can be found at https://www.moldpres.md/en/news/2021/08/14/21005913 *Demonstrating your COVID-19 status: Moldova will accept the proof of COVID-19 recovery and vaccination record. Your appointment card from vaccination centres is not designed to be used as proof of vaccination and should not be used to demonstrate your vaccine status.
A number of further exemptions exist, as set out below under Quarantine requirements. You should contact your travel operator and air carrier for more information before travelling to Moldova. You should check for updates on border crossings with Ukraine and Romania on the Moldovan Border Police website< /a>. *Quarantine exemptions: The following quarantine exemptions apply: • children up to the age of 12 are fully exempt
• people in transit, who are not spending more than 24 hours after their entrance was recorded in Moldova
• students coming for studies, exams, or academic contests upon presenting confirmation papers;
• crew and service personnel of aircraft, ships, and trains;
• persons summoned by Moldovan law enforcement institutions;
• persons traveling for health reasons, including the attendant;
• personnel involved in providing humanitarian aid;
• diplomatic passport holders and their family members accredited to the Republic of Moldova and International UN staff;
Arrivals who are in self-isolation may take a PCR test or a rapid antigen test on the 7th day of their visit, and will not have to continue self-isolating if the test is negative. You are allowed to enter the Transnistrian region without a negative PCR test.


Internal Restrictions:
*Travel in Moldova: There are no local travel restrictions in place in Moldova.
*Accommodation: Most hotels are open with no restrictive measures in place.
*Public places and services: The Moldovan government announced a new public health state of emergency, which will be in force until at least 30 November 2021. Markets, restaurants and bars can operate usual hours, including food delivery services. Malls and commercial centres are operating usual working hours (until 10pm). Schooling is both online and in-person. Nightclubs are closed. Private events such as weddings or birthday celebrations are not allowed. Restaurants, cafes, theatres, cinemas and concert halls are open, but access will only be permitted upon presentation, either on paper or electronically, of one of the following documents (for persons over the age of 18):
• a COVID-19 vaccination certificate evidencing full vaccination; • a negative PCR test result taken no more than 72 hours before the event;
• a negative rapid antigen test result taken no more than 48 hours before the event;
• confirmation of the presence of COVlD-19 antibodies (serological antibodies test).The document is valid for a period of 90 days from the date of the test.
You must also carry one form of photo identification as well as your COVID-19 document such as a passport or driving license.
You must wear a mask outside at mass gatherings, and in enclosed spaces such as supermarkets, restaurants, bars and on public transport. Officials have the authority to issue fines for non-compliance. Social distancing of 1m must be observed.
*If you test positive for COVID-19, you may need to stay where you are until you test negative. You may also need to seek treatment there.
